children.name: fine
children.definition: to make sb pay money as a punishment: phạt tiền
examples: Inspectors have the power to fine any passenger travelling without a ticket.
fine sb £5/$100 etc
The company was fined $1.6 million for breaking environmental regulations.
be fined £10/$100 etc
She was fined $300 for reckless driving.
fine sb for (doing) sth
One player was fined for fighting during the game.
The state fined the company for safety violations.
be/get fined
You will be fined for any lost library books.
fine[C noun] an amount of money that you are ordered to pay as a punishment: tiền phạt
a fine for (doing) sth
A fine will be imposed for overstaying your visa.
The penalty is a $250 fine for the first offense.
a heavy finea large fine
There are heavy fines for drink-driving.
He got a $75 fine for speeding.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a $1000 fine.
a library fine/parking fine etc
If you’re going into town, will you go and pay my library fines for me please?
get a finebe told to pay a fine : bị phạt tiền
I got a £100 fine for speeding.

children.name: punish
children.definition: to do sth unpleasant to sb because they have done sth wrong, for example by putting them in prison, or making them do sth that they do not want to do: trừng phạt
examples: She was suspended while the school decided how to punish her.
punish sb for (doing) sth
His parents punished him for disobedience.
The U.S. threatened to take away trading privileges as a way to punish the country for human rights violations.
Two instructors were punished for harassing female students.
He punished the classbygivingthem extra work.
The oil company was found guilty on ten counts of pollution, and was punishedwitha $250 million fine.

children.name: teach sb a lesson
children.definition: to punish sb because you want to make sure that they will not behave badly again:dạy ai đó 1 bài học
examples: I hope a night in the cells has taught you a lesson.
He was treating me badly, so I left - I just wanted to teach him a lesson.

children.name: make sb pay U
children.definition: make sb pay informal to do sth unpleasant to sb as a way of punishing them for sth bad they have done to you or sb you know: bắt ai đó trả giá
examples: If I ever find out who did this, I’ll make them pay!
make sb pay for
I wanted to make my father pay for his betrayal.
The prosecution asked jurors to make Mr. Sanderson pay for what he did.

children.name: penalize
children.definition: /penalise  to officially punish sb, especially by taking away their right to do sth or by limiting their freedom in some way : trừng phạt
examples: New laws will penalize firms that continue to pollute the environment.
It is unfair that the whole class should be penalized because of the bad behaviour of a few students.
penalize sb for (doing) sth
A referee may penalise players for wasting time.
The House of Representatives voted to penalize him for ethics violations.

children.name: discipline
children.definition: to punish sb who has broken the rules of an organization that they belong to or work for: trừng phạt (người phạm quy định của một tổ chức )
examples: Officers are expected to discipline soldiers who do not keep their uniforms in good condition.
be disciplined
Anyone who is regularly late for work is likely to be disciplined or dismissed.
Even when Morton and Collins started fighting on the field, neither player was disciplined.
be disciplined for
Asenior civil servant has been disciplinedforrevealing secret government plans to the media.

children.name: be punished
children.definition: /biː ˈpʌnɪʃt/  to bepunished forsomething bad that you have done:
examples: bị trừng phạt
▪ If you commit a crime you must expect to be punished.
be punished for:bị trừng phạt vì
▪ Ellen was punished for being rude to her teacher.
be severely punished:bị trừng phạt nghiêm trọng
▪ Anyone who disobeyed his orders was severely punished.

children.name: pay for sth
children.definition: pay for/ˈpeɪ fɔːʳ/  to suffer for having done something wrong, especially for breaking the law:
examples: trả giá
▪ I’ve spent the last three years in jail. I tell you, I’ve paid for what I did.
pay dearly for somethingbe severely punished for something:
trả giá cho cái gì đó
▪ People who sell drugs to our children should pay dearly for it.
pay forsthphrasal verb trả giá (lỗi lầm)
to be punished for doing something bad to someone else, or to sufferbecause of amistake that you made
_We all pay for our mistakes in some way at some time.
_He tricked me and I'm going to make him pay for it!

children.name: take the rap
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ðə ˈræp/  informal to be punished or held responsible for something bad, especially for something you did not do:
examples: nhận hình phạt
▪ Until the cause of the accident was proven, the company made it clear that it was not willing to take the rap.
take the rap for (doing) something:nhận hình phạt vì cái gì đó
▪ The defense argued that Green was set up to take the rap for the murder of Roy Robinson.
▪ I prefer driving; I don’t want to take the rap for getting lost.

children.name: face the music
children.definition: /ˌfeɪs ðə ˈmjuːzɪk/ informalto be ready to accept punishment for something you have done:
examples: hứng chịu hậu quả, chấp nhận trừng phạt
▪ Rather than face the music at a trial, Abingdon chose to plea bargain.
face the music
to accept criticism or punishment for something you have done

children.name: punishment
children.definition: sth that is done to sb in order to punish them: hình phạt
examples: In cases of sheep-stealing, the usual punishment was hanging.
punishment for
Punishments for bad behavior can range from time-outs to withdrawing privileges, such as television

children.name: penalty
children.definition: an official punishment often involving paying money for sb who breaks a law, a rule, or a legal agreement: hình phạt
examples: The law carries a penaltyofup to three years in prison.
The protesters were told to clear the area around the building,onpenaltyof(= the punishment would be) arrest if they did not.
Currently, ticket holderspaya penalty equal to 25% of the ticket price when they change their flight plans.
There was a penaltyclausewhich said you had to pay half the cost if you cancelled your booking.
penalty for
The penalty for treason was always death.
They asked for themaximumpenaltyforhoax calls to be increased to one year.
a heavy/ severe/ stiff penalty
The contract includes stiff financial penalties for failure to complete the work on time.

children.name: sentence
children.definition: the official punishment that someone is given by a judge when a court decides that they are guilty of a crime, especially a period of time in prison:
examples: Belfast Appeal Court increased his sentence from five to nine years.
a heavy/ light sentencea long or short time in prison:
Evans was given a light sentence in return for giving information to the police.
a prison/ jail sentence : án tù
Moore began an eighteen-month prison sentence in November.
a life sentencewhen sb is in prison for the rest of their life] án chung thân
Hailey is serving a life sentence, and is reported to be in poor health.
a death sentencewhen the punishment is death
Richardson was convicted of murder and given a death sentence.
a 7 year/ 6 month etc sentence[when sb has to go to prison for 7 years, 6 months etc]
Neale is finishing a three-month sentence for petty theft.
a maximum/ minimum sentence[the longest or shortest time that sb can be sent to prison for a crime]
If convicted of the charges against him, Blackburn could receive a maximum sentence of 30 years.
pass sentence[officially say what a criminal’s punishment will be]
Judge Evans will pass sentence on the three men tomorrow.
serve a sentence (for sth): thụ án vì cái gì đó
He was recently freed after serving a sentence for leading anti-government riots.
serve a 2-year/10-year etc sentence: thụ án 2 năm/10 năm
Perrault is serving a 15-year sentence for fraud and tax evasion.

children.name: retribution
children.definition: when sb is severely punished for what they have done: sự trừng phạt
examples: Employees need to be able to express their feelings without fear of retribution.
She was asked whether a civilian government shouldseekretributionagainstmilitary officers involved in human rights abuses.
retribution for
Some officials felt that the bombings were retribution for the killing of the hijackers.
They fled because they feared retributionforthe genocide.
divine retributionretribution from God : trời phạt
The earthquake was seen by some people as divine retribution.
Many saw her death asdivineretribution (= punishment by God)forher crimes.

children.name: sanction
children.definition: a strong action taken in order to make people obey a law or rule, or a punishment given when they do not obey : biện pháp trừng phạt; biện pháp chế tài
examples: Without realistic sanctions, some teachers have difficulty keeping order in the classroom.
a range of sanctions aimed at deterring insider abuse.

children.name: come down on
children.definition: sb toimmediatelypunish someone for something they have just done, because you want to make it clear that their actions are completely unacceptable: phạt ai
examples: come down on sb for
Mrs Green really came down on him for swearing.
come down heavily/hard on sbpunish someone very severely:
In the examinations we shall come down hard on any student who attempts to cheat.
The authorities are threatening to come down more heavily on drink-driving offences.

children.name: throw the book at
children.definition: sb informal if sb in authority throws the book at sb, they give them the severest punishment that can be given: phạt nặng
examples: Unless you plead guilty, the prosecutors will throw the book at you.
Superior Court Judge Stephen Rosen threw the book at Davidson, sentencing him to six years in prison and ordering him to pay $1.6 million in restitution.

children.name: get/be given U
children.definition: get/be given to be officially given a punishment: nhận (một loại hình phạt )
examples: He deserves to get at least 10 years in prison.
You’ll probably just get a fine.
McLean was given a life sentence for his part in the bombing.

children.name: be condemned
children.definition: formal to be given a particular punishment by a court, especially a severe punishment:
examples: be condemned to 20 years/life imprisonment etc:
Thomas McMahon was condemned to life imprisonment for killing Lord Mountbatten.
be condemned for murder/robbery/theft etc
He was taken away after being condemned for robbery and armed assault.
be condemned to death
Lewis was condemned to death after a trial lasting a year and a half.
condemned man/woman/prisonersomeone who is condemned to death:
The prison rules allow no communication with a condemned man.

children.name: when sb is likely to be punished
be in trouble
children.definition: if you are in trouble, you are likely to be punished because you have done sth bad: gặp rắc rối
examples: You’ll be in trouble if they catch you cheating.
be in trouble with
My sister’s in trouble with the police again.
get into trouble
I’ll get into trouble if my parents see me smoking.

children.name: have it coming U
children.definition: have it coming informal use this to say that someone deserves to be punished or deserves something bad that happens to them : đáng bị như vậy
examples: A lot of people think the murdered man had it coming.
have it coming to
He had it coming to him, the jerk.

children.name: take the law into your own hands
children.definition: take the law into yourown hands to do sth illegal and often violent in order to punish sb because you know the law will not punish that person : tự xử lấy
examples: One day, after years of violent abuse from her husband, she took the law into her own hands.

children.name: ticket
children.definition: a printed note ordering you to pay money because you have done something illegal while driving or parking your car: giấy phạt; biên lai phạt
examples: a parking/ speeding ticket
When I got back, there was a traffic warden by the car and a parking ticket on the windscreen.’

children.name: disciplinary
children.definition: intended to punish someone for breaking a rule or law or to force them to obey rules: kỷ luật (mang tính răn đe, trừng phạt)
examples: disciplinary action/ measures/ charges etc:
The committee members promised that appropriate disciplinary measures would be taken against the offenders.
So far, not a single person has faced prosecution or disciplinary action over the case.

children.name: punitive
children.definition: intended as a punishment: răn đe trừng phạt
examples: punitive action/ measure/ sanctions etc
Government forces immediately took punitive action against the rebels.
The sanctions were a punitive measure used to try to force South Africa to reject apartheid.
The UN has imposed punitive sanctions on the invading country.
punitive damages[legal] [money that a person or company has to pay to someone they have harmed] tiền bồi thường thiệt hai theo quán quyết tòa án
The company was ordered to pay punitive damages in a sex discrimination case.
She is suing the newspaper for $5 million punitivedamagesclaiming they knew the article about her was untrue.
